newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish shares rebound, seen extending gains.
newsitem.headline: Polish shares rebound, seen extending gains.

text.p: Polish shares on Monday rebounded after a two-day fall and analysts said that though the stronger buying after price-fixing signalled another gain on Tuesday, Monday's stable turnover suggested slow growth.
The main WIG index, currently at 14,656.5 points, set a 30-month high at 14,832.7 points last Wednesday.
"If more capital doesn't flow in we're not going to be able to significantly beat our recent high, rather we'll oscillate around it," said Artur Czerwonski of Bank Pekao SA brokerage.
Some analysts said a possible rate rise in the United States on Tuesday could be dampening foreign stock buying.

The main market's all-share WIG index rose 1.1 percent to 14,656.5 points and turnover inched up 0.6 percent to 104.5 million zlotys ($37.4 million) on both markets. Gainers led losers by 59 to seven with 12 stocks flat.
Analysts said large-cap bank stocks that showed strong selling after price-fixing such as BPH, BRE and Bank Slaski may hit a correction on Tuesday after recent gains.
But they said top gainer Bank Komunalny, which jumped seven percent to 24.5 zlotys ($8.8), might continue rising from last week's debut at 23 zlotys ($8.2).
Analysts also said biggest loser brewer Zywiec, down 6.4 percent, fell in profit-taking but should rebound on Tuesday.
Continuous trade turnover was at 1.7 million zlotys ($0.6 million) with biggest mover steel trader Stalexport up 3.9 percent.
NFI units rose 7.4 percent to 137.5 zlotys ($49.2) in a 31.3-million-zloty ($11.2 million) turnover and dipped 0.4 percent in a continuous trade turnover of 10 million zlotys ($3.6 million).
